name: Avoid Empty Finally Block When Calling Resource
description: This metric reports all artifacts calling database with at least one empty finally block (empty or only containing comments).
output: This report lists artifacts calling database resources with an empty finally block.
rationale: Finally blocks must be used to execute the code that is needed after either the try and/or the catch block have been executed. It is usually the place to code the release of resources used in the try block. As such, an empty finally block is most probably the sign of potential "resource leaks" that will jeopardize the application's stability.
remediation: In a try and catch/finally statement, finally blocks should contain code to handle the thrown exception.
total: Number of artifacts calling database resources
alternativeName: Avoid Empty Finally Block When Calling Resource

technicalCriteria.name: Programming Practices - Error and Exception Handling

qualityStandards.name: Empty Exception Block
qualityStandards.description:
Objective
Avoid improper responses to unusual and unexpected situations

Consequence
Software without consistent and complete handling of errors and exceptions makes it impossible to accurately identify and adequately respond to unusual and unexpected situations.

Measure Element
Number of instances where an exception handling block (such as Catch and Finally blocks) of the named callable and method control elements does not contain any other control element

qualityStandards.name: Empty Exception Block
qualityStandards.description: An invokable code block contains an exception handling block that does not contain any code, i.e. is empty.

qualityStandards.name: The application must not be subject to error handling vulnerabilities.
qualityStandards.description:
Error handling is the failure to check the return values of functions or catch top level exceptions within a program. Improper error handling in an application can lead to an application failure or possibly result in the application entering an insecure state. 

The primary way to detect error handling vulnerabilities is to perform code reviews. If a manual code review cannot be performed, static code analysis tools should be employed in conjunction with tests to help force the error conditions by specifying invalid input (such as fuzzed data and malformed filenames) and by using different accounts to run the application. These tests may give indications of vulnerability, but they are not comprehensive.

In order to minimize error handling errors, ensure proper return code and exception handling is implemented throughout the application.
